reviewText:
I have combination skin, which means my forehead, chin, and top of nose region gets extremely oily and the nostril and cheek region gets extremely dry. I have tried a variety of skin care products and this is the only one that can balance the oils on my face. It helps heal breakouts and prevent new ones; and is the only product that helps with my acne. This product is also great for mild to severe sunburns; apply generously to affected area and you will feel the cooling effect immediately. Regular application(twice/ thrice a day) to sunburnt area helps heal the burn and peeling skin. The ingredients separate easily because it is a combination of clays and glycerin, so make sure you shake the bottle well before each use to ensure smooth application.

The product is good for 5 years from the date at the bottom of the bottle (date of manufacturing) . E.g., if the date is Aug 16 (2016), then your bottle of the lotion is good until Aug 21(2021).

I have been using this for years and would definitely recommend it to people with all skin types.

reviewText:
At first, this smells very fruity with some complexity to it with the patchouli. I'm not a fan of patchouli, but the initial scent from this when sprayed is actually quite beautiful!  However, that floral / fruitiness quickly goes away and the patchouli steps in to punch you square in the face like a prize fighter.  Seriously, you have to really, REALLY love patchouli to love this one. One of the positives of this is the bottle. It's really pretty to look at, as well as the dangling hearts. They are not cheap plastic as I thought it would be, but rather, they are made from metal. They're kind of heavy actually, but I think they really add to the charm of the bottle's look.

I'm glad I purchased it, because I had been really curious, but it's definitely not a favorite of mine.

reviewText: I absolutely LOVE perfumes. I especially LOVE perfumes in cool looking bottles. So when I was offered the Jenna Jameson Heartbreaker Perfume at a reduced price in exchange for my honest review I knew I had to accept it. When I first received this product and smelled it my first thought was it smelled like something my grandmother would wear. It was very strong and not what I thought it would smell like. However, this is one of those perfumes, at least for me, that you have to actually put on and let your own body chemistry decide on the smell. After spraying the perfume on my wrist the scent completely changed and I actually really liked the scent. The bottle is very pretty also. It's a ruby red color with two silver colored hearts on it. After actually trying the perfume on I would definitely recommend it to friends and family.

reviewText:
I use a lot of perfume, I go through a new bottle every couple of weeks, and I never bought the same scent twice. I`m still looking for my favorite scent. This is not going to be it. I`m going to use it, but definitely not purchase again. Someone else may like it, it just does not lure my scents. Bottle is a very pretty, red glass, and it smells classier, than the name suggests.

I got this for evaluation, 50% off, in order that I might provide this review.

* I originally gave this 3 stars, but as I tried to use this further, I found the smell being just completely wrong. I asked three friends separately, what they think of it, and each one said, that this smells manly. And that was the exact word I was looking for. First two girls did not want to take this from me for free, the third one took it, but stated that really just a little at a time can be used. I downgraded this to 1 star, as it was in fact unusable and I wasted money on it. All four of us are in our early to late twenties and none of us liked this perfume. This is the only one 1 star review I ever wrote.

reviewText:
Not gonna lie, I am a fan of Jenna's so I was excited to receive this today and it didn't disappoint. The bottle is this beautiful red and gold with heart charms that are attached to the perfume bottle lid. It has an sexy and confident mix of floral and musky scents that most women would love and it doesn't over power the senses like some perfumes do when you first put them on. My only problem with Heartbreaker is not knowing which occasion to wear it because it smells good enough for pretty much all of them.

*I received this at a discounted price for my 100% honest review.

Ok about the perfume, comes in a VERY SEXY red bottle, and the heart charm on there you see in the pics, that IS NOT PLASTIC, it is a heavy duty SILVER CHARM, very nice touch, if your girly your gonna love this, now if I had to compare it and LUCKILY I am familiar with it, is Avon's Imari the maroon bottle, to me it is very similar to that one.  I put this on as soon as it came in the mail, yes I was excited, and it lasted all day, when I got in bed under the blanket and got cozy I could still smell it on my wrist, so that was nice to see is that it did not wear off even after several hours, oh and it is a FULL SIZE not a tiny sample.  I was invited to purchase this at a promo price in return for a full honest review, I would definitely recommend this to all friends and family, and tell my guy friend to check it out for their Ladies :) If you like Imari you will like this, I love them both <3, And yes I am putting it on my repurchase list here on Amazon. reviewText: I really want to thank the writers of fragrance reviews here on Amazon as well on many other sites. I'm a complete perfume addict, and since I don't go out of the house but prefer to shop online, I buy a lot of fragrances "blind", using only the reviews to predict whether I'll like a scent or not.  I decided to try this gem due to the extremely good price as well as all of the many positive reviews it has received.  My bottle arrived months ago, and I've really been LOVING this, especially in the Fall and Winter months (although I feel it is suitable no matter the season).  Until my obsession for perfumes really bloomed, which was relatively recently, I had mostly stuck to my two favorite scents (Ralph Lauren Safari and Elizabeth Arden Red Door).  Amongst all of the new fragrances I've added to my collection since then, this is one of my favorites.  Just a delicious, warm, comforting scent. I personally feel that this is a very sexy scent, but it is also a scent I enjoy wearing while just lounging around the house in pajamas, reading or binge-watching a TV show.  When I tried this perfume, on my first spray I got a heavy alcohol smell. Don't give up! It wasn't long before it was gone, thankfully. Then came the most alluring, delicious even, sweet floral fragrance. I'm not picking up the berry note that is among the notes listed.  Instead, on my skin I am smelling the divine floral notes. Not long after that, on the dry down I enjoy the experience of the oh-so-yummy warm notes, which typically last for several hours. I think this is a very comforting and very sensual fragrance. It has gotten a prominent place on one of my perfume trays since it arrived...and I just may be ordering a second bottle while the price is still so low!
title: Jenna Jameson Heartbreaker Perfume for women 3.4 oz Eau De Parfum Spray

reviewText:
I'm an environmentalist.  My goal in buying a old-style shaver and blades was to reduce my impact on the environment.  I had considered a straight razor, but all the stropping and honing seemed a bit too much for me, and my barber told me that even many barbers are unable to do it properly.  So I settled on the old style razor.  No plastic, and you can recycle the blades!

All well and good.  However, I was unhappy with the packaging of the blades.  Instead of receiving a nice little box of 200 blades, I received 40 five-blade packages!?!  Ugh.  What a waste packaging material.

I would suggest to any person intending to buy a 200 blade package to call and confirm that you'll get a single 200 blade package.

That being said, the razor blades themselves function well.  They are cheap, and they work nearly as well as contemporary razors.  They are much more environmentally friendly than contemporary razors because they are not made with any plastic.

reviewText:
I took up DE shaving years ago and had bad experiences cutting myself. Derby was the culprit. I cut myself with these as well. I never cut myself with the Astra Greens. Astras work better for me until I gain skill with DE shaving to move up to these super sharp and non-forgiving blades. I'm still in the experimental phase just 2 months in, and haven't perfected the art yet. For someone that has better technique, I'd recommend these.
Pros:
sharp like a sword
Cons:
not for beginners like myself

reviewText:
Their OK for a beginner, but their really not sharp enough for a real close shave.  I bought these to begin with because they are forgiving.  I then progressed to Derby and now I use Feather. If you have bumps or moles, or tricky curves, you don't want a super sharp blade until you get the hang of what you're doing.

DE shaving requires your complete attention.  It is not like cartridge shaving and you don't want your mind wandering.  If any of these areas I mentioned apply to you, I would start with these blades, and progress as experience dictates. If I don't have twenty minutes to shave, I now use Derby.

If you like this review make sure to use a pre shave oil prior to the cream with these blades in particular. Cremo shaving cream is my standard.

reviewText:
I'm giving this three stars because it's not awful in and of itself, and I judged it against what I think are the 2 best blades on the market.

I saw a youtube video with a guy shaving with my same Muhle R41 and touting these blades.  I found them to be absolutely unbearable next to the Feathers and the Astras.  In fact, these seemed to provide an exacerbated version of the downsides of each of the other blades.  They were far less sharp than the Astras but somehow far prone to nicking and irritating than the feathers.  To put this in perspective, I can definitely shave with Feathers and avoid nicks/irritation.  I cannot do so with these.  Perhaps I got a bad batch?  I wouldn't rule it out, but with my 100 pack of Astras, I won't feel the need to try other blades again any time soon.  Astra for a daily shave, and Feathers for special occasions, or when I have more time to shave.

reviewText: There are better razors out there, even at lower costs but may not be as readily available as these. I would consider these to be solid middle level razors with decent shaving action (but nothing superb). If you have thick hair, this may not be good enough. If you prefer to pay more for better quality, then something like Feather and KAI, both from Japan are great, and if you prefer to pay less and still go higher up in quality you can try something like Astra, which is from Russia. These Wilkinsons are from Germany and come packed in a convenient plastic case per five blades and each blade individually wrapped in paper.

reviewText:
The "tried-and-true" trusted brand of blades that my dad used to use, and which I started shaving with when I was younger.....Good standard quality and they fit most single-blade razor holders.

And these single blades shave just as smoothly as the triples do: They hold their sharpness well after several shavings (My beard is more on the "rough scraggly side" so I have stiffer beard hairs and often wear-out the sharpness of the other triple blade razors after only 2 or 3 uses, but each of these Wilkinson's Blades stay sharp over 5 or 8 uses or more.)

Very pleased with the price, which, after years of buying triple-blade razor and forking over large sums of cash for sets of only 5 or 8 blades, I was able to buy 30 blades at only a fraction of the cost of the triple blades....When I purchased these, it was $1.87 for a set of 5 blades (that's just 37 cents a blade; compare that to the exorbitant cost of a single triple-blade model in the store, which are around $2 or $3 EACH)

Blades like these aren't often found in the stores these days, so I was happy to find these online and at such an affordable price....Definitely will repeat and buy more in the future.

reviewText: Many, many years ago, when the Trac II razor came out, Mad Magazine did a spoof where the manufacturers created cartridges with five blades in them, pointing out how ridiculous that would be. It was later animated for a Saturday Night Live spoof commercial.  Here we are in the present and there are cartridges on the market with five blades in them that cost $3.00 - $4.00 apiece.  All the nonsense you hear about how more blades are better is just that, marketing nonsense.  These will shave you just as well or better and they cost a Quarter each, plus you can buy a perfectly good safety razor here on Amazon that will cost $30.00 that will last a lifetime.

reviewText:
Using this in my Merkur 37c SLANT BAR.

I already had a 100-pack of Astra SP, but I am still new-ish to DE safety razors, so I'm still inquisitive enough to try a few blades. So far Astra SP is the best. Wilkinson was a close second and I don't regret trying it, but I won't buy again. The value isn't there. It was still a bit rougher than Astra. Others I've tried so far are Van Der Hagen (Germany), which came with my Van Der Hagen razor and Merkur (by Solingen), which came with my Merkur 37c Slant. Van Der Hagen blades are tolerable, Merkur blade was forgettable. I have relegated all of these to "clearing the runways" - trimming the sideburns, for which I use the regular DE (not as easy with slant). I have also recently tried Feather and the first shave was rather nice, but the second was rough - I suspect they are a "one shave blade", which makes them too expensive and not worth it.

I will probably give them as samples to friends and maybe try it once or twice more in each of my razors and will update if I have any news.

reviewText:
Provide a clean and comfortable shave. A little pricier than bargain blades but they shave WORLDS better than some of the cheaper brands like Personna. I can also compare them to Feather, which a lot of people rave about.  Feather shave very smoothly and they are fine on my face, but they give me TERRIBLE razor burn on my neck.  WS blades are the best of both worlds, extremely sharp and also extremely smooth and forgiving on the skin.

They come in a plastic box which can safely hold your used blades.  I've been very happy with them.  You can get a 100 pack for less than $20 that will last you 1 - 2 years.  Don't waste your time trying to pinch pennies on inferior blades, this is your face you're talking about!

PROS:
* Extremely sharp, but also smooth shaving
* Coated with chromium, ceramic, and teflon.  In my experience this does deliver a smooth shave
* Comes with plastic boxes for blade disposal.  Many cheaper brands do not.

CONS:
* On the pricier side.  Still, you can buy 100 of these for less than 20 bucks...

OVERALL:
* My go-to blade.  Great combination of sharpness and smoothness.  For me, unbeatable.

reviewText: The vintage, British version of the Wilkinson Sword shaving blade is a modern classic, and is still sold online at inflated prices. reviewText:
There is always a trade-off between sharpness and comfort, and unfortunately these blades didn't work well for me in either category.  Even right after a shower and with good shaving cream, I found going against the grain to be quite uncomfortable.  I really needed to pull the razor through the hairs, which is never good.

Everyone has different preferences when it comes to safety razors, but these really do not hold their edge too long, and they aren't that sharp to begin with.  Sword blades are definitely a notch above Murkers, but I would suggest getting either Kai or Feather blades.  Those will allow you to cut will very little effort, thus reducing irritation.

reviewText:
I give them 5 stars because they're of consistent manufacture. I've tried these out for a while now, off and on, over the last year. The experience I get from these are very consistent from blade to blade. Other blades I've tried occasionally throw a bad blade in. I haven't seen that with these.

Now, about the blade, this is a very mild edged blade. If Feather and Personna Lab are 9.5-10/10 in terms of sharpness, I would rate these somewhere in the neighborhood of Derby. These would rank a 2-3/10. Don't be mislead by that, it speaks nothing to the quality of the blade or the shave. Matter of fact, this is a fine blade. There is a perfect blade and razor combo for every face that is going to vary based on skin and beard type. If you find that Feather are too harsh, try a medium blade, like Astra SP, and if that's also hard on you, give these a whirl. Conversely, if these are chewing your face up, try out Astra SP. They're an excellent quality 6/10 sharpness blade.

Personally, I don't like these blades for my face. Lord, Derby, and the like are just too mild for me. These pull and tug as I shave, a good indication that the blade is too mild. That aside, they are friendly and easy to shave with. In spite of the immediate discomfort, they leave me with smooth, irritation-free shaves, hence I don't mind continuing to test them. And I can use the blade for a week of daily shaves and see little or no change in the performance of the blade.

And just a tip, when trying out a new blade, before passing final judgement, give it a solid week of shaves with a single blade. Even if the first round isn't great, give it a solid week, or 4-7 shaves, to really evaluate the blade fairly. Your first shave might be atrocious, but I've found with some blades that once the first shave or two passes, I get the best shaves I could ask for. Other blades I find I can use for two weeks of daily shaves with good results, which I would not have known if I never evaluated the deterioration of the edge over time. And other blades start out giving me great shaves, but they peter out quickly, leaving me with 3-4 good shaves before I have to change blades. Personally, I'll sacrifice the best shave I can get for a blade that I can change out once a week and still get a great shave with. But in the end, it's all about what pleases your senses, not mine, so happy shaving!

reviewText:
Are you looking for razors that not only do the job, but are able to do the job time and time again?  What if I told you that you can use the same razorblade for several weeks possibly even MONTHS, and they only get slightly dull as time goes on?  That's exactly what makes Wilkinson Sword razors MUCH better than every other razorblade company I've tried thus far.  The best part is that these excellent razors are sold relatively cheap at your local Dollar General store.

Get this, I'm NOT making this up.  I shave every 3-4 days (I have to otherwise I get really itchy!).  From July of last year until January of this year, I've been using exactly ONE Wilkinson razor the whole time.  By late October it finally got a little dull, but it didn't completely wear out until January of this year.  If I can go 6 months using the same exact razor... why bother buying any other brand of razors?  It's clear to me that Wilkinson Sword is the best.

I highly recommend ignoring popularity, ignore the ads you see on TV (particularly during sporting events) showing off the top name companies with some pretty boy shaving happily in his bathroom mirror while some generic cheesy macho music plays in the background, and go with Wilkinson Sword.  They won't let you down.

reviewText:
These blades use a proprietary coating made of both teflon and ceramic (most other blades only use teflon). This coating not only helps the blade last longer but also makes the blade super slippery and easy to drag across your face even if you don't have the impeccable technique necessary for sharper blades like Feathers. The reason the coating helps the blade last longer is that when DE blades wear out it is not as much because of the metal wearing out as it is the coating wearing off. The only disadvantage to how slippery these blades are is that you won't feel it when you are pressing too hard and you can easily cut yourself without realizing it. Remember your technique: no pressure, let the razor do the work, and these blades will reward you with unparalleled comfort.

In terms of sharpness these blades are in the medium to high range. They are sharper than Sharks but less sharp than Feathers. I would actually strongly recommend these to beginners over any other beginner DE blade such as Shark, Astra, or Derby because of the incredible smoothness when using these.
title: Wilkinson Sword Double Edge Razor Blade Refills for Men - 5 Count

reviewText:
I chose this rating because of the overall experience I had while using the Wilkinson Sword DE razor blades. I am a new proponent to wet-shaving and I have been experimenting with different blades, trying to find the best one for my skin/beard type. I have only tried three brands so far: Dorco (Korea) Derby Extra (Turkey) and the Wilkinson Sword (Germany). These blades seem to work very well for me and my skin/beard. I found that the Dorcos gave me an okay shave, considering my experience so far and the Derby's ...well, I didn't care for them much, they seemed to be too dull for my liking but again this is with somewhat junior experience. The Wilkinson sword left my face feeling nice and smooth after two passes and I ended up with no nicks or cuts. As far as longevity, I have not yet put them to the test but for most blades, I have been getting 5-7 shaves. I truly think that the way sharpness feels is personal. Each different blade will feel different to each person.

I would recommend these blades to anyone who is searching for a blade that is sharper than most "starter" cheaper blades but not so sharp that it will bloody up your face and neck. And for the price, they are a good choice.

reviewText:
Today was my first ever wet shave.  I used a Merkur 23C, a Wilkinson Sword blade, an Omega boar brush and Proraso soap (bowl lathered). Previously I was using Shick Quattro Titaniums. I gave this four stars because it worked well for me; however I am not certain it is worth five stars until I try some other blades.

reviewText:
TL;DR  These are good, sharp blades and provide an extremely close shave. Possibly my favorite blade where cost is no concern. Feather is sharper, but doesn't provide a better shave in my experience. Astra SP Platinum is not quite as sharp, but is half as expensive and still quite comfortable.

Here is my review of the blades I've tried. There are a lot of sampler packs on Amazon, but after doing some research I chose to order around 30 each of just a few different blades to try, avoiding all of the lesser-quality "filler". I'll compare here and there to Mach-3 blades since that's what I previously used before switching to electric, and now this.

First off, Derby is what came with my razor. These you can practically rake across your face any way you see fit. They aren't very sharp, on par with a Mach-3 that's been used a few times. Shaving requires more strokes which leads to more irritation, especially on the neck. That said, I'd say these are a good blade if you're super worried about cutting yourself, because it's practically impossible. But even beginners might want to look elsewhere as these blades kind of ruin the "shaving experience". Don't be disappointed if you just bought this razor and have only tried these blades! Keep reading...

I ordered a 100-pack of Astra SP Platinum (that's Astra Superior Premium Platinum, not the regular stainless) since it's under ten bucks at the time of this writing. These are great. Beginners, start here. They're sharp enough that you don't have to press the razor against your skinwhich you shouldn't have to! You're supposed to let the weight of your razor do the work as you guide it along your face in short strokes. So naturally, these are sharper than Mach-3 blades, but if you do press a little, you probably won't nick yourself. I love these blades because for me, they're comfortable enough for everyday use and provide good, close shaves at a very inexpensive price. Easy on my neck with care. My go-to blade. Great for beginners and pros alike, and eligible for Subscribe & Save!

Wilkinson Sword Classic seem to be great blades for people who have their technique down pretty well. Compared to Astra SP Platinum, they are sharper. They provided the best shave of the lot, but I did nick myself here and there on my neck and below my chin the first time around. Do not push these blades against your skin. It doesn't take much mastery to use these, and they're worth working up to. Downside: more than twice the price of Astra SP Platinum. I'll keep some of these around for days when I want the closest shave possible, or I just feel like something different. If you're new to traditional shaving or think Mach-3 blades are sharp, maybe don't start here, but definitely try them out.

Feather "New Hi Stainless" Platinum Coated blades are exactly what the reviews say: sharp. My first shave I got a good amount of nicks, but my second I had almost none. I adapted well, and you have to; each brand is a little different and the best require good technique, but some are more forgiving than others. These are negligibly sharper than the Wilkinson Sword Classic but they aren't forgiving at all and I didn't achieve any better of a shave. They're incredibly sharp compared to a Mach-3 blade. At 2x the price of the aforementioned and more than 3x the price of Astra SP Platinum, I won't be keeping these on hand, but your mileage may vary. If you only want the sharpest blade around, this is it. Fun fact: these come ten to a pack instead of five.

In conclusion, I'm sticking with Astra SP Platinum for regular use and Wilkinson Sword Classic when I'm up for something sharper. I shave every other day, and either is priced reasonably enough that if I want, I can use each side of a blade just once for a fresh edge every shave. That's about a 100-pack every year, so do the maths on price. Of course, both brands last much longer than this if you're looking for even better value.

reviewText: I've used the Wilkinson Sword blades for about three weeks now, and so far they have give me a nice comfortable shave with my safety razor.  The blades are sharp but not too aggressive.  To give you a frame of reference, I shave a two to three times a week.  My beard is average thickness and my skin is a bit sensitive.  So far, this blade suits me well because I'm getting a close shave, but with no irritation or razor burn afterwards.  The only other DE razor blades I've tried are the Derby blades.  I like them also, but the Wilkinson's I feel are a little bit sharper.  Durability is quite good too.  After three weeks, the Wilkinson blade is still quite sharp and will probably last another three to four shaves easily.  The Derby blades got dull much quicker.  As with many shaving products, it's all personal preference.  If you are somewhat new to safety razor shaving, part of the learning process is to find the right blade that suits you.  I'm still in the process myself and will be trying other brands, but I am happy with the Wilkinson's.  These blades are definitely worth a try and they're not that expensive.  Hope this helps someone.  Thanks!

reviewText:
I am relatively new to the art of wet shaving with a safety razor, but I'm proud to say I have become more adept at using one. The Parker 99R that I own came with some Shark Super Chrome blades which I did not care for very much. After researching different blades online(I'll include one of the links I found to be particularly helpful), the Wilkinson Sword blades became my weapon of choice! They are sharp yet extremely forgiving and the synthetic polymer coating definitely makes for a less irritating shave!

I religiously try to shave every morning so I've never had a beard or any heavy facial hair growth. However my hair seems to grow back quickly so that 5 o' clock shadow always bothered me. The Wilkinson Sword blades gave me a superb shave that reduced what stubble I had into smooth skin. I've also found I can get a close shave with fewer passes and in a shorter amount of time than the Shark Super Chrome blades I had originally used. I have had no nicks or cuts either, which surprised me given how aggressive the blade can be with hair.

I know there are many other types of razor brands out there(I recommend buying a sample pack), but Wilkinson Sword seems to be the perfect match for my needs. If you're lucky enough to have the same experience as I did with these babies then I hope this review helped! Here's that link I promised to those of you who are still unsure:

reviewText:
I introduced my dad to using a safety razor a couple years ago. He tried Wilkinson blades and found them to be sharper and give a cleaner shave than the Merkur blades. I started having problems with the Merkur blades, too--nicks, razor burn, etc. I learned through some research that Wilkinson makes the sharpest blades on the market. So, at dad's suggestion, I tried them again and love them. They cut close to the skin, don't leave nicks (unless I forget to change the blade), and don't leave razor burn. I think I was too inexperienced when I first tried them.

Just for reference, here's my original review from a few years ago: Usually I use Merkur blades, but I saw these available and figured, "I'm sure they'll be fine." The blades felt dull; they were flimsy, and a couple of the blades in the pack had grime on them when I opened them. My skin was irritated like never before and I got more small cuts than I had from my safety razor since...well, ever, really. Immediately, I hopped on Amazon and ordered a pack of the Merkur blades.

reviewText:
I've been shaving solely with a safety razor, soap and brush for over a year now.  Not only does it save a LOT of money (the only consumables are the blades, and in the year, I've spent $12 or so on blades, and the soap - I just purchased my 3rd "block" for about $3 each), but it does make me feel a little manlier.

I've used 4 different brands of blades, and so far, these are definitely the best.  The smoothest, sharpest, etc.

Each blade is individually "sealed" by being wrapped in wax paper, etc.  This prevents them from rusting simply due to humidity in the bathroom (which 3 of the 4 other brands i've used did - just sitting in their plastic container waiting).  This makes them smoother, and sharper, for longer.

Pro-tip: if you store your razor in mineral oil between shaves, each blade can last for WEEKS, this can cut down the replacements on these too! (this works for any razor though - the oil displaces the water, which causes the rust, which is 90% of the reason they dull)

reviewText: If you want "the best a man can get" then this is it. These blades are great! They are manufactured in Germany and are very well-made. With Wilkinson I use a Merkur Classic "Barber Pole" long safety razor which I got here from Amazon. I brush on a little sandalwood shave cream and a few smooth moves later I'm soft as a baby's... well, you know. It's nice to engage in one of those forgotten rituals that remind a man why it's great to be a man. Proper shaving has become a lost art for most men, but it doesn't have to be for you. Today's average man hasn't a clue about the fine art of the traditional wet shave that our grandfathers used to take part in because we've been conditioned to accept the cheap and disposable multi-blades that companies market today - because it makes them rich, not because it's a better product. Those blades are far too expensive and dull too quickly. Plus, they get clogged and these fine Wilkinson blades don't. If you want a smoother shave, if you want to save money, if you want to reduce your environmental impact, and if you want to engage in a ritual that great men like your grandfather, John F. Kennedy, and Teddy Roosevelt took part in, then buy these blades. You won't regret it.

reviewText: I used to shave with the Gillette twin blade razor. That is, until they came out with the triple blade 'system' - when I switched over to that. After a while they came out with the Quattro and I said, "What the heck, lets keep up with the times". Finally, when Gillette introduced the Schtick (or some such monstrosity) a bulb went on in my head. It seems to me that they want to innovate for the sake of innovation. That's when I decided to try out the old tried and tested solution and know what? I am never going back. It used to take me atleast 4-5 rinses every time I shave using a multiple blade 'system'. That's because the blades are so close together that hair gets trapped between the blades. They promise you a closer shave and all that, but I haven't seen any difference. My double edged razor - the same one that my dad and probably his dad used to shave with - gives me a very close shave and I only rinse once and even then I just hold it under water and all the hair is gone. With the Gillettes I used to have to rub it with my fingers to get all the hair off! Not the least is the feeling of manliness you get when you shave with a double edged razor. Yes, it's not a straight edge, but this is why I like it. It is innovation where they've made a good product (straight edge) better and safer! I use a Merkur Long Handled Safety Razor with these blades. Best decision I've made in a long time.

Walmart actually carries a ladies version, I just wish they would distribute the men's formula for retail purchase again.  So far I cannot find it retail in my market area. reviewText:
I'm one of those guys that has had persistent chapped lips since childhood, and nothing ever seemed to help. Chap sticks might make them feel better for a minute, but never actually heal.

Well, I first found this stuff in a $1 bin on my way to the checkout at MEC (Canada's REI) -- man, I wish I'd bought a case of them at that price! This stuff works like a dream and, despite the tiny size, lasts for quite a while. If I had to guess, my last one followed me for over a year.

The annoying thing is that it's bigger than most, meaning it's bulky if you want to just jam it in your jeans. However, that also means I don't seem to lose it. Come to think of it, I don't think I've ever misplaced one of these, unlike those 'disposables'.

reviewText:
I'm incredibly disappointed that Unilever continues to modify this formula making it worse all the time.  This used to be an excellent product before they modified the formula.

It used to turn the bath water green and full of long lasting bubbles and a wonderful scent.  In it's current formula the bubbles do not last long at all, it's not near as concentrated anymore, and it has a somewhat blue/green color that fades instantly.

The only reason I've been buying it is because I still like the scent but I'm searching for an alternative.

This is just another unfortunate example of a company getting greedy and changing the formula to obtain more profits.  I've contacted the company to let them know but based on their response they really don't care what their customers think.

reviewText:
The container makes it appear that this is the Classic Badedas that many customers have loved for years. However, the container is the only similarity to that product. Apparently Unilever, which now owns this company, has changed the formula. You'll know that from the pink sticker that says new formula (in German), and even more from the changed product. It no longer has that wonderful Badedas smell. It no longer turns your bath water that weird but familiar green. It does make a lot of suds, but they are like the suds from liquid dish soap.

I don't understand why Unilever changed this product. Perhaps some of the ingredients became too expensive? Perhaps they did market research showing that customers wanted something different? That is hard to believe given all the negative comments I've seen online, but perhaps there are satisfied customers who aren't writing in. I'm not among them.

reviewText:
I am a longtime fan of Badedas and was so pleased to find it reasonably priced on amazon almost 3 years ago.  I have continued to order pretty regularly and after running out of my last bottle, I placed an order for another as usual.

However, imagine my disappointment tonight after sliding into the thick bubbles that my bath water wasn't the fresh green Badedas color. What's up with that?

Poured a little out of the bottle into my hand and instead of the weird yellow-green, it came out a clear blue-green.

The scent fades too once it's in the water. Where it used to fill my entire bathroom and bedroom with it's lovely alpine fresh scent, it's now just a pale shadow of the Badedas I fell in love with all those years ago.

My first through was that I got a fake. After a quick internet search, I found out that Unilever changed the formula. I am so completely heartbroken and will not be ordering Badedas again until they change it back.

reviewText:
When I would sleep over my Oma's as a child she would always get out the Badedas Classic for bathtime and I absolutely loved it.  Unfortunately, when I went to buy a bottle for myself I was sorely disapointed. The top of the bottle came with an ugly pink sticker proudly proclaiming "Neue Formel", which to my dismay meant New Formula.

It's now much darker, and is almost blue in color.  It does not change the bath water to that lovely spring green, does not smell as good, and did not leave my skin feeling as clean.  The bubbles, if you care about them, were plentiful though.

This does not appear to be counterfeit, as I read other complaints about the change on the German amazon reviews and on a Badedas facebook page.

All in all, I will not be buying again until I hear the formula is changed back.

reviewText: I bought this one because I was fooled by the "classic" written on the bottle and the "made in Germany". If you are used to the wonderful smell of Badedas, you'll find this formula much messed with! The maker is now "Unilever". I have a bottle I bought in the UK (also made in the UK) which smells like the true "classic" one, but it doesn't advertise it on the bottle. I compared the two formulas and they are different. This one smells different, as if it were made with cheaper ingredients. That characteristic strong pine-horse chestnut smell is gone. Even the colour has been messed with. It dilutes into a cheap, artificial, almost urinous yellowish-green that makes you want to run away from the bathtub.

reviewText: I purchased Badedas because I have loved Vitabath for many years and was assured that Badedas was virtually identical. As it costs signifcantly less, and there have been complaints about the quality of recent purchases of Vitabath, I thought it was worth a try. While both are thick green bath gels, the smell is very different.  Vitabath has a light, clean, refreshing scent while Badedas has strong musky undertones that I can only describe as smelling like a combination of stale sweat and cheap perfume. I do realize what smells good or bad can be highly subjective, and many truly seem to like the scent of Badedas but it definitely does NOT smell like Vitabath  and if you purchase it as a substitute you will most likely be disappointed. I find the smell unpleasant enough to render my purchase useless.  (My husband concurs, so it's not just me!)

reviewText:
Honestly, just toss out all other bubble bath products.  This one is made with lactic acid (excellent for women's skin in particular, if you do your research) and horse chestnut extract along with a fragrance you won't find in any American-made bath product except Vitabath.  (And the original Vitabath Spring Green formula is essentially a more expensive version of this product; and in my opinion inferior.  I use Vitabath Original when I run out of Badedas.)

The quality is top-notch; you don't need to use any soap with this product if you're using it as a bubble bath.  It cleans you.  And it seems to clean the tub as well, because this is the *one* product I have ever used that:

1) Gets you a "shower-fresh" clean feeling from a bath (Usually baths relax me, but showers make me feel "clean" ...)
2) Requires absolutely no clean up - you're clean and so is your bath tub; no residue to bath tub ring AT ALL
3) Everyone in the family loves; men and women will both appreciate the unisex "forest/clean" smell.  It's hard to describe yet you'll never forget it once you smell it.

This isn't something you can just go pick up at the store in the US (usually, unless you live in New York or L.A.) - so Amazon provides an easy way to keep a supply of this on hand.  Buy a bottle for your wife (or, heck - yourself) - you won't regret it.  Also makes a very unique gift - the receiver of said gift, if American, has likely never tried any bath product even close to this.

The quality can't be beat, at any price.  Stock up.

reviewText:
Got hooked on this while a student in Berlin in the 70s. It's true that Vitabath is nice, but not the same and not as rich. Used to get it in Aruba, but somehow it disappeared from there. Then found a place in Florida that sold it--for a price. A few years ago, while living in Paris, some German friends visited and brought me a bunch. That, I'm embarrassed to admit, is when I learned that it's pronounced ba-day'-dahs, not bah'-da-das. Finally the bunch ran out and I discovered Amazon. This is a good price. Not as good as in Germany nearly 40 years ago :-) but good. This stuff is rich, makes masses of long-lasting bubbles and has a soothing, strong herbal smell. I'm a gin drinker and it seems like the perfect bubble bath for someone who loves those potent smells. Nothing relaxes me like a long, hot Badedas bath.

Just read that Badedas has a hint of patchouli, which is distressing as I despise Patchouli. Have never noticed it in all these years however, and will try and pretend I don't know it's there.

reviewText:
This has a fragrance and consistency identical to that of Vitabath Spring Green, for those familiar with that product. The Badedas version is more fun to own, because the label is in 3 languages (no English, though!) and you'll feel like a beauty maverick making niche discoveries, even though Badedas is as ubiquitous in Germany as Irish Spring is here.  All I can say about this delightful product, which I've repurchased again and again, is that it is in a class by itself. It is so super-concentrated that one teaspoonful on a bath pouf will get you squeaky-clean, as will one tablespoonful (about 1/3 capful) in a full bath. The color is really cool-- it makes the bathwater glow green! But, more important, the fragrance is aromatherapeutic pampering at its best (cool, green, herbal, and piney, but not overly antiseptic or masculine) and the formula delivers a wonderfully refreshed clean feeling. I don't know what the horse chestnut extract does exactly, but I do know that a hot Badedas bath can make up for a long night shift, a rough afternoon with the kids, or just about anything else life can dish out. It restores me down to my soul, and makes me smell wonderful for hours.

My only caveat would be for those with dry or sensitive skin-- this is a highly fragranced, highly detergent product and isn't particularly skin-softening, especially if you are used to Dove or Caress-type body washes with added moisturizers. It doesn't bother me at all; I just use lotion on my arms and legs if need be. But if you are sensitive to strong cleansers and fragrances, you may want to proceed with caution.
title: Badedas Classic Vital Bad Bubble Bath, 25.5 Fluid Ounce

reviewText:
I remember using Badedas as a kid more than 20 years ago and just loving the scent.  On a nostalgic whim, I searched for this product on Amazon three months ago and was surprised to find it.  I initially bought the shower gel version but found that it did not live up to what I remembered - the scent was just not as distinct or unique.

A month later, I decided to order one bottle of the bubble bath version after seeing a picture of the bottle -- it looked similar to the bottle I remembered from more than 20 years ago.

This bubble bath version of Badedas was definitely much better and lived up to my expectations.  The scent was a little stronger --- fragrant, but not overpowering.  The bottle was marked as a bubble bath, but had just the right viscosity and solubility for use as a body wash.  It was simply perfect and I have been using it ever since as a body wash -- I've found that very small amounts are sufficient for use as a body wash and still have not gone through a bottle in almost two months.  A little caution is needed when pouring it out as the bottle spout is just a normal, round opening which makes it easy to pour too much out.

reviewText:
I'll be honest: I bought this because it had high reviews. I wasn't really satisfied with the bubble bath varieties I've found in the local grocery store, and did a search for the highest rated bubble bath on Amazon.

I wasn't crazy about the scent at first. The bottle was larger than I expected, and the first whiff made me wonder if I'd use it all. It's a sort of woodsy pine, a much more masculine smelling bubble bath than I'd ever experienced (I am a woman). Upon using it, it turned my bath water absinthe green (awesome!) and generated a dense, luxurious foam that grew into am alarmingly large mountain of bubbles. A little of this stuff goes a long way, and a quarter of a cup was certainly excessive (note: the directions on mine are in German. I have no idea how much I was supposed to use, but trial and error is half the fun).

After about half an hour in the tub, I'm happy to report that I really do love the smell. It's relaxing without being cloying, and my skin feels incredibly smooth. Five stars!

reviewText:
I bought 2 bottles based on reviews here. I was looking for a less expensive alternative to Vitabath moisturizing bath & shower gelee. It smells about the same, but is better suited to a bubble bath than a shower gel. It is drying to the skin when used as a bath gel, which I believe is due to the propylene glycol. Most of the organics found in Vitabath seem to be missing.

Vitabath Original Spring Green moisturizing bath & shower gel (partial list): Helianthus Annuus (Sunflower) Seed Oil, Aesculus Hippocastanum (Horse Chestnut) Seed Extract, Equisetum Arvense Leaf Extract, Zea Mays (Corn) Oil, Lanolin Oil.

Badedas: Aesculus Hippocastanum (Horse Chestnut) Seed Extract, that's about it for the Badedas.

In short, Badedas smells good, has cool German label, but I really miss the Vitabath. If I were using it in a bath rather than a shower, I'd probably be more pleased. I'm using it up, but hope to find a sale on Vitabath one day soon, and use this as a backup.

reviewText:
Update 3/7/15-- The formula for Badedas has been changed by Unilever, and I no longer recommend this product. Several significant ingredients have been omitted, the pine scent is gone, the consistency is thinner, and the experience like an ordinary bubble bath. Save your money, this is not the original German formula Badedas many people used and loved for decades...

Original review from 2009: "It's Good To Be Bad"  I was introduced to Badedas bubble bath about 30 years ago by my sister, who said the stuff had near-magical properties (it does). She said it's full of unusual botanicals (true), makes tons of long-lasting bubbles (yup), smells incredibly good (oh yeah), and leaves the tub sparkling clean (also true).  The cost back then was around $1 an ounce.

  I've become mostly a shower-taker, but recently, when my 20-year-old bottle of Bededas turned up empty, I decided to revisit the stuff.  Remembering my sister's warning that the "Vita-Bath" products are an American copy of Bededas without all the great botanicals, I was looking for the genuine article.  Lo and behold, I found it on Amazon, of course, from several dealers at various price-points.  Smallflower (aka Merz Apothecary of Chicago) seems like a reputable dealer, selling the real deal, and even with somewhat exorbitant shipping, the price is now LESS than $1 an ounce.  Pretty good for 30 years.  Shipping was quite fast, by the way, and the product arrived UPS on the sixth calendar day after ordering.

  This Badedas (now owned by Sara Lee!) is apparently the original formula, made in Germany, with the horse chestnut oil that helps make it so magical. It also contains limonene, a very citrus-scented hydrocarbon derived from plants, and linalool, a more floral-spicy scented chemical found in over 200 species of plant.  Not the kind of stuff you'd find in your average drugstore bubble bath.  The overall scent is somewhat pine-y, and incredibly fresh and pleasant.

  A small amount of Badedas added to running hot water makes a lot of luxurious bubbles.  The overall sensation is one of slight skin-softening without the oiliness you get with some products.  Also, a slight sense of skin-tightening, but this is somewhat subjective. USE NO SOAP in a Badedas bath-- you don't need any.  Just a washcloth or sponge, and you leave the bath feeling quite clean.  Badedas seems to absorb dirt and body oils and odors into solution, and it all goes down the drain, leaving you, and your bathtub, quite clean.  Remarkable stuff.

  If you ever take a bath for relaxation, or even a wash-up, I'd highly recommend Badedas.  Smallflower has an excellent price on this 25.5 ounce size, and if you take one bath a week, this bottle should last you at least two years!  Badedas is a wonderful luxury bath product, and would make a terrific gift for a bubble bath fan, or even yourself and/or your mate.

reviewText: This product has been packaged and repackaged for years -- I use this "Bubble Bath" as shampoo, body wash, and to make bath salts and scrubs.  Horse Chestnuts have a peculiar musky chlorophyl scent that is it's own thing.  It isn't mint, or bay, or citrus -- it's musky.  But not in a Brut aftershave way.  It's subtle, and it combines with men's and women's scents differently.  It's in the range of expensive patchouli, but much lighter.  It won't make women in spandex spontaneously appear and want you, stupid.  But it does smell good.

reviewText:
I bought this creme when I was on vacation in Europe.

My Information:  My razor is a Trac II. I have a very heavy beard and sensitive skin.

A small amount is all that is needed, and it makes a thick, creamy, mildly fragrant foam on your face.  It softens my beard very well, and the blade glides over the skin.  You can re-moisten your face and re-shave over an area without problem.  Rinsing your face leaves it soft, smooth, and stubble-free!

I have used many foams and gels looking for a close shave without irritation; the best American brand for me is Gillette Gel.  I think that this Nivea creme does a better job, and I highly reccommend this product, especially if you have a thick beard with sensitive skin.  The 67ml tube lasted about 35 shaves.

reviewText:
I have been using Nivean Shaving Creme in a tube since 1980, when I first bought it in Germany. It is the Gold Standard of shaving creams. I have always stocked up when in a country where it is sold.

I have used it with multi-blade cartridges, where all you have to do is rub it on your face with your fingers, and it works great. I currently use it with a double-edge safety razor, but because of the single blade one is using, it is better to use a brush to get it on; a bowl is not necessary, just put a dime-size amount on the brush and make circles on your face to make it lather.

Finally, it is only sold in stores in Germany, Canada, Belgium, the Netherlands Spain, and possibly others. I have no idea why is isn't sold in countries like the US, UK, Italy, etc. But the Amazon price is pretty darn close to the price in these countries, and it is much easier than driving into Canada to buy it, unless you're in Buffalo or Detroit.  :^)

Sure, you can get it in a can, but all that air, all those chemicals: The tube of shaving cream has all the good stuff, and no wasteful bad stuff. And Nivea has always had the best version of every product they sell. The Shaving Creme continues that great tradition.

reviewText:
After watching all the YouTube videos about this and searching all my local haunts I decided to buy it here.
One of the main reasons is that I love the post shave balm.
I was looking for something that was easy to travel with (I squeezed it into a 2 oz twist cap bottle)
It came packaged nice and on time.
The only reason I gave it 4 stars is that it does not seem to lather as well as I had hoped and does not provide the cushion I am used to.
The smell is quite nice and not overpowering and it travels well.
I guess I will have to wait to get back from my trips to use the straight razor.
title: Nivea Razor Creme (tube) 3.4oz shave cream by Nivea
Cleaned Reviews: After watching all the YouTube videos about this and searching all my local haunts I decided to buy it here One of the main reasons is that I love the post shave balm I was looking for something that was easy to travel with I squeezed it into a oz twist cap bottle It came packaged nice and on time The only reason I gave it stars is that it does not seem to lather as well as I had hoped and does not provide the cushion I am used to The smell is quite nice and not overpowering and it travels well I guess I will have to wait to get back from my trips to use the straight razor

reviewText: I have to start by saying that I love natural soaps and this is one of my favorites. My husband on the other hand is not a fan of essential oils and he thinks their smell is too strong for him. I was shocked to hear that he loved the smell of this soap and this is when we started fighting over it! It is not drying on the skin and leaves a wonderful smell that we both love (we use Ylang Ylang and Frankinsence and Myrrh)! I have also tried other scents by this soap, but these seem to be our favorites. The only drawback is the price, the bars are too small and sell for almost $5 and at the rate we go through them it is becoming a luxury...
title: ZUM Zum Bar Anise Lavender, 3 Ounce

reviewText:
I want to counter all of the comments stating that the soap does not last long. I have been using the same bar for a month now (1 shower/day) and will likely get another week out of it. I have been storing the bar directly on my shower ledge out of the water stream. Recently I purchased a soap saver to set it on, simply to get rid of the soap puddle. I'm not sure why people aren't having the same results as me. I can only assume they are leaving the bar in a direct water stream.

Also, LOVE how this soap feels and smells. I also recently purchased the 5 pack of frankincense and lavender. I think I'm set for shower soap for the next 6 months!

reviewText:
I had very high hopes for this particular soap seeing as the ratings were really high. Unfortunately, my experience hasn't been as great as what others have posted.

I would like to start by saying that the soap does smell amazing and my body smells great after my shower and my skin feels very soft.

However, we just received the soap on Tuesday and it's now Friday evening (used Wed, Thurs and Friday) and I have posted pictures of what is left of the soap. I really expected at $8 a bar it would last 2 people, showering once a day each, more than it has.  I do keep the soap in a soap dish with holes so it's not sitting in water when it's in the dish, and it's also at the back of the shower so the shower head doesn't spray near it.

Also the dark top edge fell off, so in my picture you can see where we've just pressed it back on to the bar of soap.

I think I could have given it 4 stars if it weren't for me already using another frankincense & myrrh soap from another company that also smells great, leaves my skin soft, but it's cheaper for an ounce more and lasts quite a bit longer (it's also 100% natural).
